DOC.HEAD: U.S. Invasion Upsets Noriega's Pen Pal
DOC.TEXT: The 12-year-old girl who corresponded with Panama's Gen. Manuel Noriega is standing by her deposed pen pal. Sarah York said Wednesday she was upset with the U.S. invasion of Panama and was worried about the safety of Noriega, who went into hiding. ``I hope that he's doing OK and nothing bad will happen to him,'' she said. ``He's very nice and intelligent and seems like the kind of person someone can trust. He never let me down and I feel like I can trust him. ... ``I'm really disappointed about what our two governments are doing and I feel for the safety of Panamanian and United States soldiers.'' Sarah struck up a correspondence with Noriega following his 1988 indictment on U.S. drug charges. She has visited the dictator twice, first as his guest last year, then in October on her own. Noreiga called her a ``meritorious daughter'' of Panama. Her parents, criticized for allowing the visits, condemned the invasion. ``We are a family among the American people who support the Panamanians in their struggle for self-determination and sovereignty,'' Pauline York said in a recorded telephone message at her home. ``We join the people and the nations of the world in calling on the president and his military to end this invasion. To the Panamanian people: Todo por la patria,'' which means ``all for the motherland,'' the recording said.
